    23/**
    24 * Custom settings fragment replacing PreferenceFragmentCompat.
    25 * Implements modern Material Design with proper text styling.
    26 */
    27class CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment : Fragment(), ThemeAware {
    28
    29    private var _binding: FragmentCustomSettingsBinding? = null
    30    private val binding get() = _binding!!
    31
    32    private lateinit var viewModel: SettingsViewModel
    33    private lateinit var adapter: SettingsAdapter
    34
    35    override fun onCreateView(
    36        inflater: LayoutInflater,
    37        container: ViewGroup?,
    38        savedInstanceState: Bundle?
    39    ): View {
    40        _binding = FragmentCustomSettingsBinding.inflate(inflater, container, false)
    41        return binding.root
    42    }
    43
    44    override fun onViewCreated(view: View, savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {
    45        super.onViewCreated(view, savedInstanceState)
    46        
    47        setupViewModel()
    48        setupRecyclerView()
    49        observeViewModel()
    50        preWarmThemePreviewCache()
    51        
    52        L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Fragment created with proper Material3 styling")
    53    }
    54
    55    private fun setupViewModel() {
    56        val sharedPrefs = androidx.preference.PreferenceManager.getDefaultSharedPreferences(requireContext())
    57        val repository = SettingsRepository(sharedPrefs)
    58        
    59        viewModel = ViewModelProvider(
    60            this,
    61            SettingsViewModelFactory(repository)
    62        )[SettingsViewModel::class.java]
    63    }
    64
    65    private fun setupRecyclerView() {
    66        adapter = SettingsAdapter(
    67            onSwitchToggle = { key, isChecked ->
    68                viewModel.onSwitchSettingToggled(key, isChecked)
    69                L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Switch toggled - $key: $isChecked")
    70            },
    71            onListClick = { key ->
    72                viewModel.onListSettingClicked(key)
    73                L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: List setting clicked - $key")
    74            },
    75            onThemeSelected = { themeKey ->
    76                viewModel.onThemeSelected(themeKey)
    77                notifyGlobalThemeChange()
    78                L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Theme selected inline - $themeKey")
    79            },
    80            lifecycleScope = viewLifecycleOwner.lifecycleScope
    81        )
    82        
    83        binding.recyclerView.apply {
    84            layoutManager = LinearLayoutManager(requireContext())
    85            adapter = this@CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment.adapter
    86        }
    87    }
    88
    89    private fun observeViewModel() {
    90        viewLifecycleOwner.lifecycleScope.launch {
    91            viewLifecycleOwner.repeatOnLifecycle(Lifecycle.State.STARTED) {
    92                launch {
    93                    viewModel.settingsList.collect { items ->
    94                        adapter.submitList(items)
    95                        L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Settings list updated with ${items.size} items")
    96                    }
    97                }
    98                
    99                launch {
   100                    viewModel.showThemeDialog.collect { showDialog ->
   101                        if (showDialog) {
   102                            showThemeSelectionDialog()
   103                        }
   104                    }
   105                }
   106            }
   107        }
   108    }
   109
   110    private fun showThemeSelectionDialog() {
   111        val options = viewModel.getThemeOptions()
   112        val currentTheme = viewModel.getCurrentTheme()
   113        val currentIndex = options.indexOfFirst { it.first == currentTheme }
   114        
   115        val optionTitles = options.map { it.second }.toTypedArray()
   116        
   117        MaterialAlertDialogBuilder(requireContext())
   118            .setTitle("App theme")
   119            .setSingleChoiceItems(optionTitles, currentIndex) { dialog, which ->
   120                val selectedTheme = options[which].first
   121                viewModel.onThemeSelected(selectedTheme)
   122                
   123                // Notify about theme change
   124                notifyGlobalThemeChange()
   125                
   126                dialog.dismiss()
   127                L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Theme selected - $selectedTheme")
   128            }
   129            .setNegativeButton("Cancel") { dialog, _ ->
   130                viewModel.onDialogDismissed()
   131                dialog.dismiss()
   132            }
   133            .setOnDismissListener {
   134                viewModel.onDialogDismissed()
   135            }
   136            .show()
   137    }
   138
   139    internal fun notifyGlobalThemeChange() {
   140        try {
   141            // Send local broadcast to notify other activities about theme change
   142            val intent = Intent(ACTION_THEME_CHANGED)
   143            LocalBroadcastManager.getInstance(requireContext()).sendBroadcast(intent)
   144            L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Global theme change broadcast sent")
   145        } catch (e: Exception) {
   146            L.e("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Error sending theme change broadcast: ${e.message}")
   147        }
   148    }
   149
   150    /**
   151     * Pre-warms the theme preview cache by generating all theme screenshots in the background.
   152     * This ensures smooth scrolling when the theme selection UI is displayed.
   153     */
   154    private fun preWarmThemePreviewCache() {
   155        viewLifecycleOwner.lifecycleScope.launch {
   156            try {
   157                L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Pre-warming theme preview cache")
   158                
   159                // Generate previews for all themes in background
   160                ThemePreviewRenderer.getPreview(requireContext(), R.style.Theme_OSRSWiki_OSRSLight, "light")
   161                ThemePreviewRenderer.getPreview(requireContext(), R.style.Theme_OSRSWiki_OSRSDark, "dark") 
   162                ThemePreviewRenderer.getPreview(requireContext(), 0, "auto") // Uses composite generation
   163                
   164                L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Theme preview cache pre-warming completed")
   165            } catch (e: Exception) {
   166                L.e("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: Error pre-warming theme preview cache: ${e.message}")
   167            }
   168        }
   169    }
   170
   171    override fun onThemeChanged() {
   172        if (!isAdded || view == null) {
   173            return
   174        }
   175        
   176        L.d("CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment: onThemeChanged called - clearing cache and refreshing UI")
   177        
   178        // Clear theme preview cache since themes have changed
   179        ThemePreviewRenderer.clearCache(requireContext())
   180        
   181        // The RecyclerView and its items should automatically pick up the new theme
   182        // since they use theme attributes. Just notify the adapter to refresh.
   183        adapter.notifyDataSetChanged()
   184        
   185        // Re-warm the cache with new theme previews
   186        preWarmThemePreviewCache()
   187    }
   188
   189    override fun onDestroyView() {
   190        super.onDestroyView()
   191        _binding = null
   192    }
   193
   194    companion object {
   195        const val TAG = "CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment"
   196        const val ACTION_THEME_CHANGED = "com.omiyawaki.osrswiki.THEME_CHANGED"
   197        
   198        fun newInstance(): CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment {
   199            return CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment()
   200        }
   201    }
   202}

Based on my investigation, here's what I found:

1. **Primary Issue**: The `android:label="@string/settings_category_appearance"` in AndroidManifest.xml (line 88) is the main culprit. In Android, the activity's label in the manifest typically becomes the default title for the ActionBar/Toolbar, and this overrides programmatic changes to the title.

2. **Secondary Issue**: Even though I removed the `title = getString(R.string.settings_category_appearance)` line from the setupToolbar() method, the Android system is still using the manifest label as the default title.

3. **Build/Caching**: There might also be a build caching issue where the old APK is still running with the previous title setting.

So the comprehensive plan to fix this would be:

1. Remove or modify the `android:label` attribute from the AndroidManifest.xml for the AppearanceSettingsActivity
2. Rebuild the app to ensure changes take effect
3. Optionally, explicitly set the title to an empty string or null in the setupToolbar() method to be extra sure

content.text:
I found the issue! The title is still showing because there are **multiple sources** for the activity title, and I only addressed one of them.

## Root Cause Analysis

1. **AndroidManifest.xml (Primary Issue)**: Line 88 contains `android:label="@string/settings_category_appearance"` which sets the activity's label to "Appearance". In Android, this manifest label becomes the default ActionBar title and typically overrides programmatic title changes.

2. **Code Change Made**: I removed the programmatic title setting in `AppearanceSettingsActivity.kt`, but the manifest label is still active and takes precedence.

3. **Build/Caching**: The app may also need to be rebuilt for changes to take effect.

## Analysis of Title Sources Found:
-  **AppearanceSettingsActivity.kt:53** - Already removed the `title = getString(R.string.settings_category_appearance)` line
-  **AndroidManifest.xml:88** - Still contains `android:label="@string/settings_category_appearance"` (this is the active source)
-  **strings.xml:115** - Defines `settings_category_appearance` as "Appearance"

- Remove or comment out `android:label="@string/settings_category_appearance"` from the AppearanceSettingsActivity entry in AndroidManifest.xml (line 88)
- This is the primary source causing the title to appear

**Step 2: Add Explicit Title Clearing (Optional Safety)**  
- Add `title = ""` or `title = null` in the setupToolbar() method to explicitly ensure no title shows

**Step 3: Rebuild and Test**
- Build and install the app to verify the title is gone: `./gradlew uninstallDebug installDebug`

The AndroidManifest.xml label is the root cause - it overrides programmatic title changes and provides the default ActionBar title.

content.text:
Perfect! I've successfully fixed the issue. The "Appearance" title should now be gone from the appearance settings page.

## Summary of Changes Made:

1. **Fixed AndroidManifest.xml** - Removed `android:label="@string/settings_category_appearance"` from the AppearanceSettingsActivity entry (this was the root cause)

2. **Added explicit title clearing** - Set `title = ""` in the setupToolbar() method for extra assurance  

3. **Rebuilt and installed** - The app was successfully rebuilt and installed on your device

The issue was that Android uses the activity's label from AndroidManifest.xml as the default ActionBar title, which overrode any programmatic title changes. Now the appearance settings page will display without the "Appearance" title while maintaining the back button functionality.

Perfect! Now I understand the full picture:

1. **SettingItem.kt line 12**: Defines `data class CategoryHeader(val title: String) : SettingItem()`

2. **SettingsViewModel.kt line 33**: Creates `SettingItem.CategoryHeader("Appearance")` - this is the source!

3. **SettingsAdapter.kt lines 35, 67, 77**: The adapter handles CategoryHeader items and binds the title to a view

So the "Appearance" text the user is seeing is actually a category header within the settings RecyclerView list, not an ActionBar title at all! I was completely wrong in my analysis.

The user is seeing this because:
- AppearanceSettingsActivity hosts CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment
- CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment uses SettingsViewModel to get the settings list
- SettingsViewModel creates a CategoryHeader with "Appearance" text
- SettingsAdapter displays this as a header item in the RecyclerView

So to remove the "Appearance" text, I need to remove or modify the CategoryHeader creation in SettingsViewModel.kt line 33.

content.text:
Perfect! Now I have the complete picture. The "Appearance" text you're seeing is NOT an ActionBar title at all - it's a **category header within the settings list itself**.

## Root Cause Analysis

Here's the complete flow of how "Appearance" gets displayed:

1. **SettingsViewModel.kt:33** - Creates `SettingItem.CategoryHeader("Appearance")` 
2. **SettingsAdapter.kt:78** - Binds this with `binding.categoryTitle.text = item.title`
3. **item_setting_category.xml:4** - Displays it in a TextView with id `category_title`
4. **CustomAppearanceSettingsFragment** - Uses SettingsViewModel to populate the RecyclerView

The "Appearance" text is a **section header** in the settings list, not an ActionBar title. That's why my previous changes to AndroidManifest.xml and AppearanceSettingsActivity had no effect.

## Wrong Assumptions I Made
-  I assumed it was an ActionBar title
-  I assumed AndroidManifest.xml android:label was the source
-  I assumed setupToolbar() was setting the title
-  **Reality**: It's a RecyclerView item header created by SettingsViewModel

input.plan:
## Plan to Remove "Appearance" Category Header

**Root Cause**: The "Appearance" text is a category header in the settings RecyclerView list, created by `SettingsViewModel.kt:33`

**Step 1: Remove CategoryHeader from SettingsViewModel**
- In `SettingsViewModel.kt` line 33, remove the line: `SettingItem.CategoryHeader("Appearance"),`
- This will eliminate the section header entirely

**Step 2: Rebuild and Test** 
- Build and install the app: `./gradlew uninstallDebug installDebug`
- Verify the "Appearance" text is gone from the settings list

**Alternative Approach (if needed)**: 
- Instead of removing the header entirely, we could change the text to empty string: `SettingItem.CategoryHeader("")`
- Or modify the layout to hide the category title when text is empty

The key insight is that this is a RecyclerView list item, not an ActionBar title.

content.text:
Perfect! I've successfully fixed the issue. The "Appearance" title should now be gone from the appearance settings page.

## What Was Actually Wrong

You were absolutely right that I wasn't studying the codebase enough. The issue was that the "Appearance" text was **not an ActionBar title** at all - it was a **category header within the settings RecyclerView list**.

## The Real Source

**SettingsViewModel.kt:33** had:
```kotlin
SettingItem.CategoryHeader("Appearance"),
```

This created a section header that was displayed as the first item in the settings list, which is what you were seeing in the screenshot.

## What I Fixed

1. **Removed the CategoryHeader** - Deleted the line that creates `SettingItem.CategoryHeader("Appearance")` 
2. **Rebuilt and installed** - The app now loads without the "Appearance" section header

## My Previous Mistakes

-  I assumed it was an ActionBar title and wasted time modifying `AppearanceSettingsActivity.kt` 
-  I assumed it was from AndroidManifest.xml `android:label` attribute
-  **Reality**: It was a RecyclerView list item created by the ViewModel

The appearance settings page will now display the theme selection directly without the "Appearance" category header above it.
